\frac{d{\cal V}}{ds} + \tanh{(s + \log{\mu}) {\cal V}}  \right)^2.
\end{equation}


We may now state and prove the main result of this section.
We shall denote the
map $z\mapsto \mu z$ by $\phi_\mu$ to emphasize its parametric dependence.


\begin{thm} [global coercivity of the Hessian fails on ${\sf Rat}_1$]\label{noglo}
$\lim_{\mu \rightarrow \infty}{\tau(\phi_{\mu})}=0.$
\end{thm}


\noindent
{\it Proof:} Define the following sequence of smooth irrotational sections
$V_{\mu}={\cal V}_{\mu}\widetilde{E}_1$ of $\phi_\mu^*TS^2$
where
\begin{equation}
{\cal V}_{\mu}(s) = tqm sech}\, {s} - c_{\mu} K_{\mu}(s)
\end{equation}
and $c_{\mu}$ is a constant determined by the requirement that
$\langle V_{\mu},K_{\mu} \rangle_{L^2}=0$.
By our previous remarks, this suffices to ensure that ${\cal V}_\mu$ is orthogonal
to $\ker{\mathfrak D}^{\phi_\mu}.$
Since $V_{\mu} \in H^1(\phi_\mu^*TS^2) \cap \ker{{\mathfrak D}^{\phi_{\mu}}}$ it suffices to prove that
\begin{equation}
\lim_{\mu \rightarrow \infty} \frac{{\sf Hess}_{\phi_{\mu}}(V_{\mu},V_{\mu})}{\langle V_{\mu},V_{\mu}
\rangle_{H^1}^2}=0. \label{h1overhess}
\end{equation}
In fact, we will show that
\begin{equation}
\lim_{\mu \rightarrow \infty} \frac{{\sf Hess}_{\phi_{\mu}}(V_{\mu},V_{\mu})}{\langle
V_{\mu},{\cal E}_\mu V_{\mu}\rangle_{L^2}}=0, \label{h1overev}
\end{equation}
which implies (\ref{h1overhess}) since
$$||V||_{H^1}^2={\sf Hess}_{\phi_\mu}(V,V)+||V||_{L^2}^2 +\langle V,{\cal E}_\mu V
\rangle_{L^2} > \langle V,{\cal E}_\mu V\rangle_{L^2}.$$


To prove (\ref{h1overev}), first notice that since $K_{\mu} \in \ker{{\mathfrak D}^{\phi_{\mu}}}$ we have
$${\sf Hess}_{\phi_{\mu}}(V_{\mu},V_{\mu})= {\sf Hess}_{\phi_{\mu}}(tqm sech}\, {s},tqm sech}\, {s}).$$
Using the explicit expression for the Hessian in cylindrical coordinates we
find
$${\sf Hess}_{\phi_{\mu}}(tqm sech}\, {s},tqm sech}\, {s}) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} ds\
tqm sech}\, ^2{s}\left( \tanh{s_{\mu}}-\tanh{s} \right)^2$$
where $s_{\mu}:= s + \log{\mu}$. Since $|\left( \tanh{s_{\mu}}-\tanh{s} \right)^2| <
 4$ holds for all $s$,
$${\sf Hess}_{\phi_{\mu}}(tqm sech}\, {s},tqm sech}\, {s}) < 4 \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} ds\
tqm sech}\, ^2{s} = 8$$
holds for all $\mu$. Since ${\sf Hess}_{\phi_{\mu}}(V_{\mu},V_{\mu})$ is bounded for
all $\mu$, (\ref{h1overev}) is implied by
\begin{equation}
\lim_{\mu\rightarrow \infty}{\langle V_{\mu},{\cal E}_\mu V_{\mu}\rangle_{L^2}}= +\infty.
\label{evvinf}
\end{equation}

To establish (\ref{evvinf}), first introduce for each nonnegative pair of
integers $(m,n)$ the positive function
$$ I_{m,n}(\mu) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}{ ds\ } {tqm sech}\, ^m{s}\ tqm sech}\, ^n{s_\mu}}.$$
Clearly, the function $I_{m,n}(\mu)$ is bounded above by the constant
$I_{m,0}$.
From the definition of $c_{\mu}$ we have
$$c_{\mu} = \frac{\langle tqm sech}\, ,K_{\mu} \rangle}{\langle K_{\mu},K_{\mu} \rangle}=
\frac{I_{3,1}}{I_{2,2}}\ ,$$
and from equation (\ref{evv}) and the definition of $V_{\mu}$ we have
$$ \langle V_{\mu},{\cal E}_\mu V_{\mu}\rangle_{L^2} = c_{\mu} \left(c_{\mu} I_{4,0} -
2 I_{1,3} \right) + I_{2,2}.$$
%\intinf {\sech^2{s}\ \sech^2{\sm}}. $$
Since $I_{4,0}$ is a positive constant and $I_{1,3}$, $I_{2,2}$ are
positive and bounded above, (\ref{evvinf})  will follow
if we can establish that $\lim_{\mu\rightarrow \infty}{c_{\mu}} = +\infty$. In fact,
one can explicitly evaluate the
integrals which appear in the definition of $c_{\mu}$ to obtain
$$c_{\mu} = \frac{I_{3,1}}{I_{2,2}} =
\frac{\mu^4 - 4\mu^2 \log{\mu} - 1}{4\mu( \mu^2 \log{\mu} - \mu^2 +
\log{\mu} + 1)} .$$
%\thicksim \frac{\mu}{4\log{\mu}}
Clearly, this implies that $\lim_{\mu\rightarrow \infty}{c_{\mu}} = +\infty$ as
required.\hfill
$\Box$





\section{The case of ${\sf Rat}_n^{eq}$}
\label{ratn}
\setcounter{equation}{0}

Staying in the context of the ${\mathbb{C}}{{P}}^1$ model on $S^2$, but generalizing to
any degree sector, $n\geq 1$, things become rather more difficult. The
reason is that the isometric action of $G$ on ${\sf M}_n={\sf Rat}_n$ does not have
cohomogeneity 1, except for $n=1$. In general, then, to understand the
global behaviour of $\tau$ one must consider the $4(n-1)$ dimensional
orbifold ${\sf M}_n/G$, not simply a curve, as in section \ref{rat1}.
Reduction to a curve
 {\em is} possible, however, provided we restrict attention
to dynamics within a certain equivariance class.
Employing stereographic coordinates $z,W$ on domain and codomain as usual,
and defining polar coordinates such that $z=re^{i{\varphi}}$, one may write the
field equation for the ${\mathbb{C}}{{P}}^1$ model on spacetime $S^2\times{\mathbb{R}}$ as
\begin{equation}
\label{el}
\frac{W_{tt}}{(1+r^2)^2}-\left(W_{rr}+\frac{1}{r}W_r+\frac{1}{r^2}W_{{\varphi}{\varphi}}
\right)-\frac{2\overline{W}}{1+|W|^2}\left(\frac{W_t^2}{(1+r^2)^2}-W_r^2-
\frac{1}{r^2}W_{\varphi}^2\right)=0.
\end{equation}
This supports equivariant solutions within the ansatz
\begin{equation}\label{an}
W(r,{\varphi},t)=r^nq(r,t)e^{in{\varphi}}.
\end{equation}
Provided $q:[0,\infty)\times(-\epsilon,\epsilon)\rightarrow{\mathbb{C}}$ is nowhere vanishing
and has suitable boundary behaviour, solutions within this ansatz have degree
$n$. Substituting (\ref{an}) into (\ref{el}) one obtains a
$(1+1)$-dimensional
hyperbolic partial differential equation for $q$. The space of static
solutions is simply $q(r,t)=c\neq 0$, a complex constant. So the
equivariant moduli space is ${\sf M}_n^{eq}={\sf Rat}_n^{eq}=\{z\mapsto
 cz^n:c\neq 0\}\cong{\mathbb{C}}^\times$, the punctured
complex plane. Note that ${\sf M}_n^{eq}$ is one connected component of
the fixed point set in ${\sf M}_n$ of
the isometry group $G^{eq}=\{([\exp -in\frac{\psi}{2}\tau_3],
[\exp i\frac{\psi}{2}\tau_3]):\psi\in{\mathbb{R}}\}\cong SO(2)$, so we are assured
that ${\sf M}_n^{eq}\subset{\sf M}_n$ is totally geodesic. Both the true wave map
flow and its geodesic approximant stay within the equivariance
 class, therefore,
and one can again ask to what extent the analytic method of Stuart applies.
The equivariant configuration space enjoys a residual $U(1)$ symmetry,
namely $W(z)\mapsto e^{i\psi} W(z)$, and the discrete symmetry $W(z)\mapsto
1/W(1/z)$,
both of which leave the harmonic map energy unchanged, so we may again
restrict attention to a curve in ${\sf M}_n^{eq}$, namely
$\Gamma=\{z\mapsto \mu z^n: \mu\in [1,\infty)\}$.
The situation is actually {\em simpler} than in the full degree 1 case,
because
now the error, that is, the section of $\phi^*TN$ along which we exponentiate
to get from the holomorphic approximant to the true solution at time $t$,
must
also lie within the equivariance class. The only sections of relevance,
therefore, are irrotational sections and their $J^N$ images. We may
define a new optimal constant $\tau^{eq}(\phi)$, again the infimium
of the Hessian for $H^1$ unit sections $L^2$ orthogonal to $\ker{\mathfrak D}^\phi$,
but now
we include only equivariant sections. Since these form a subset of all
sections, we have trivially that $\tau^{eq}(\phi)\geq\tau(\phi)>0$ by
Theorem \ref{coercivity}.

Once again, we may think of $\tau^{eq}$ as a function
of $\mu\in[1,\infty)$. We first show that $\tau^{eq}(\mu)$ is continuous.
Since the setup is very similar to section \ref{rat1} we
use equivalent notation and conventions, and omit several details.
In spherical polar coordinates, the map $\phi:z\mapsto \mu z^n$ is
\begin{equation}
(\theta,{\varphi})\mapsto(f_\mu(\theta),n{\varphi}),
\qquad f_\mu(\theta)=2\cot^{-1}\left(\mu \cot^n{
\frac{\theta}{2}}\right),
\end{equation}
so $d\phi\, E_1=f_\mu'\widetilde{E}_1$ and $d\phi\, E_2=n\, {\rm cosec}\, \theta\cos f_\mu
\widetilde{E}_2$. It follows that
\begin{equation}
\nabla^\phi\widetilde{E}_1=n\frac{\cos f_\mu}{\sin\theta}e_2\otimes \widetilde{E_2},\quad
\nabla^\phi\widetilde{E}_2=-n\frac{\cos f_\mu}{\sin\theta}e_2\otimes\widetilde{E_1}.
\end{equation}
Hence, on an irrotational section $V={\cal V}(\theta)\widetilde{E}_1$,
\begin{equation}
\nabla^\phi V=V'e_1\otimes\widetilde{E}_1+Vn\frac{\cos f_\mu}{\sin\theta}
e_2\otimes\widetilde{E}_2.
\end{equation}
Given a general equivariant section $W=V+J^NU$, where $V,U$ are irrotational,
we may transfer $W$ to a neighbouring bundle $\hat{\phi}^*TN$ (where
$\hat{\phi}:z\mapsto\hat{\mu} z$) using the canonical isometry (\ref{ident}),
act with $\nabla^{\widehat{\phi}}$, then transfer back again, to obtain
$\hat{\nabla}W$. The difference between this and $\nabla^\phi W$ is
\begin{equation}
(\nabla^\phi-\hat{\nabla})W=n\frac{\cos f_\mu-\cos f_{\hat{\mu}}}{\sin\theta}
J^NW.
\end{equation}
Now
\begin{eqnarray}
\alpha(\theta)=\frac{\cos f_\mu-\cos f_{\hat{\mu}}}{\sin\theta}&=&
\frac{(\mu^2-\hat{\mu}^2)(\cos(\theta/2)\sin(\theta/2))^{2n-1}}{
(\sin^{2n}(\theta/2)+\mu^2\cos^{2n}(\theta/2))
(\sin^{2n}(\theta/2)+\hat{\mu}^2\cos^{2n}(\theta/2))}\nonumber
\\
\Rightarrow\quad |\alpha(\theta)|&\leq&
\left(1+
\frac{1}{\hat{\mu}^2}+\frac{1}{\mu^2}+\frac{1}{\hat{\mu}^2\mu^2}\right)
|\hat{\mu}^2-\mu^2|.
\end{eqnarray}
So the pullback connexion satisfies a pointwise bound of the correct type
($|(\nabla^\phi-\hat{\nabla})W|<c(\mu,\hat{\mu})|W|$ where $c\rightarrow 0$ as
$\mu\rightarrow\hat{\mu}$) and we may conclude from the results of section \ref{cty}
that $\tau^{eq}(\mu)$ is continuous.

As for ${\sf Rat}_1$, the interesting issue is the large $\mu$ behaviour of
$\tau^{eq}(\mu)$. We are so far unable to prove anything rigorous about
$\lim_{\mu\rightarrow\infty}\tau^{eq}(\mu)$ (if, indeed, it exists). However, we
make the following conjecture:

\begin{conj} For all $n\geq 1$, $\lim_{\mu\rightarrow\infty}\tau^{eq}(\mu)$
exists and is finite. For all $n>1$, this limit is not zero.
\end{conj}

\noindent
If true, the equivariant Hessian is globally coercive for degree $n$
greater than
unity. One could at least hope, therefore, to model equivariant lump collapse
accurately within the geodesic approximation in the case $n>1$.

To motivate this conjecture, we should describe some numerical work which led
directly to the proof of its $n=1$ counterpart, Theorem \ref{noglo}. It is
straightforward to write the Jacobi operator on irrotational sections as an
explicit ordinary differential operator acting on ${\cal V}(\theta)$. The
eigenvalue problem for ${\mathfrak J}^\phi$ then reduces to a singular
Sturm-Liouville problem on $(0,\pi)$, namely
\begin{equation}
\label{sturm}
-{\cal V}''-\cot\theta{\cal V}'+n^2\frac{\cos 2 f_\mu}{\sin^2\theta}{\cal V}=\omega^2{\cal V}.
\end{equation}
Here $\omega^2\geq 0$ is the eigenvalue.
The eigenfunctions of this problem form an $L^2$ orthogonal basis for the
space of irrotational sections. In particular, the eigenfunctions outside the
kernel, which we shall refer to as ``excited states'', in analogy with
quantum mechanics,
 form a basis for the irrotational sections orthogonal to
$\ker{\mathfrak J}^\phi$. If we could prove that ${\sf Hess}_\phi(V,V)/||V||_{H^1}^2=
\omega^2||V||_{L^2}^2/||V||_{H^1}^2$ is bounded uniformly away from zero for
all $\mu$
and all excited states $V$, global coercivity of ${\sf Hess}^{eq}$ would follow.
Conversely, if for one of the excited states, $\omega^2 ||V||_{L^2}^2/
||V||_{H^1}^2\rightarrow 0$ as $\mu\rightarrow \infty$, global coercivity must fail: the
one parameter family of excited states itself provides a counterexample.
Unfortunately, the ($\mu$ families) of eigensections are rather inaccessible
analytically (except in the special case $\mu=n=1$, where they are known
exactly). However, they are quite easy to construct numerically, either by
employing a specialist Sturm-Liouville solver package, or by using a
shooting method. We have tried both strategies, obtaining compatible
results from each.

The pertinent results may be summarized as follows.
For $n=1,2,3,4$ and for all excited states from 2nd to 6th (ordered by
increasing $\omega^2$), the ratio ${\sf Hess}_\phi(V,V)/||V||_{H_1}^2$ appears
to remain bounded away from zero as $\mu\rightarrow\infty$. More interesting is the
first excited state. Here the ratio remains bounded away from zero for
$n=2,3,4$, but not for $n=1$. It was by examining the
graphs of the $n=1$
first excited eigenstates that the explicit family $V_\mu$ of the proof of
Theorem \ref{noglo} was devised: the family is designed to have the same
qualitative behaviour as the numerically generated eigenstates.
In figure 1 we present a graph showing the ratio
${\sf Hess}_\phi(V,V)/||V||_{H_1}^2$ as a function of $\mu$ for the first excited
states for $n=1,2,3,4$.
These data were generated by a shooting method using a 4th order Runge-Kutta
scheme with variable $\theta$
step. The singularities at $\theta=0,\pi$ were handled
by series expansions, so the scheme shot forwards from $\theta=\delta$ and
backwards from $\theta=\pi-\delta$, applying a matching condition at $\theta=
\frac{\pi}{2}$ ($\delta$ being a small positive number, typically $0.001$).
The difference between $n=1$ and the other cases is
quite clear. Although it is impossible to be exhaustive numerically, the
results suggest that ${\sf Hess}_\phi(V,V)/||V||_{H_1}^2$ is bounded away from
zero for $n>1$, as we have conjectured.
Linhart and Sadun in a recent numerical study
of lump collapse in the
${\mathbb{C}}{{P}}^1$ model on ${\mathbb{C}}$ imposed the analogous equivariance
condition on their field equation \cite{linsad}. It is an intriguing
coincidence that they found that single lump collapse differs greatly from
the predictions of the geodesic approximation (truncated to a finite disk in
${\mathbb{C}}$), whereas the collapse of two coincident lumps is quite well modelled by
the geodesic flow.
